stem: Why use dry, clean compressed air for PAC?

choices.text: Wet, oily air extends consumable life
Dry, clean air reduces wear and improves cut quality
Air quality is irrelevant
Nitrogen is always required instead of air

rationales.CHOICE-2: Moisture and oil contaminate the plasma stream and damage consumables.

stem: What is the benefit of using dry, clean compressed air for PAC?

choices.text: Better splash lubrication of the torch
Less consumable wear and improved cut quality
No benefit; air quality does not matter
Mandatory nitrogen substitution in all cases
Wet/oily air extends consumable life
Dry, clean air reduces wear and improves cut quality
Air quality is irrelevant
Nitrogen is required instead of air

rationales.CHOICE-2: Dry, oil‑free air prevents contamination of the arc and orifices.
Moisture/oil contaminate the plasma and damage consumables.

stem: Why use dry, clean compressed air for PAC?

choices.text: Wet/oily air extends consumable life
Dry, clean air reduces wear and improves cut quality
Air quality is irrelevant
Nitrogen is required instead of air

rationales.CHOICE-2: Moisture/oil contaminate the plasma and damage consumables.

stem: Why use dry, clean compressed air for PAC?

choices.text: Wet/oily air extends consumable life
Dry, clean air reduces wear and improves cut quality
Air quality is irrelevant
Nitrogen is required instead of air

rationales.CHOICE-2: Moisture/oil contaminate the plasma and damage consumables.

choices.text: Improves cut squareness
Increases arc stretch, dross, and bevel
Eliminates dross completely
Has no effect on the cut
Improves cut quality
Stretches the arc, increasing bevel and dross
Has no effect
Cools the cut

rationales.CHOICE-2: A long arc increases divergence and heat loss, worsening dross and angle.
Too much gap increases bevel angle and slag.

choices.text: Improves cut quality
Stretches the arc, increasing bevel and dross
Has no effect
Cools the cut

rationales.CHOICE-2: Too much gap increases bevel angle and slag.

stem: A sign PAC consumables need replacement is:

choices.text: Sharper kerf and less bevel
Wider kerf, more bevel, unstable arc
Lower dross with identical settings
No change at all after many hours
Improved cut squareness
Erratic arc, widening kerf, and dross
Lower noise and smoother arc
Less bevel angle

rationales.CHOICE-2: Worn nozzle/electrode degrade jet focus and arc stability.
Worn parts cause unstable arcs and poor cuts.

stem: A sign PAC consumables need replacement is:

choices.text: Improved cut squareness
Erratic arc, widening kerf, and dross
Lower noise and smoother arc
Less bevel angle

rationales.CHOICE-2: Worn parts cause unstable arcs and poor cuts.

stem: Heavy bottom dross is usually a sign of:

choices.text: Travel speed too slow or too low amperage
Travel speed too fast
Perfect parameter match
Excessive gas dryness

rationales.CHOICE-1: Too slow or too cold allows molten metal to solidify along the bottom edge.

rationales.CHOICE-2: Slow travel allows molten metal to solidify along the lower edge.

stem: Heavy bottom dross is usually a sign of:

choices.text: Travel speed too fast
Travel speed too slow
Current too high only
Wrong shielding gas only

rationales.CHOICE-2: Slow travel allows molten metal to solidify along the lower edge.

stem: Heavy bottom dross is usually a sign of:

choices.text: Travel speed too fast
Travel speed too slow
Current too high only
Wrong shielding gas only

rationales.CHOICE-2: Slow travel allows molten metal to solidify along the lower edge.

stem: Heavy bottom dross is usually a sign of what?

choices.text: Too slow a travel speed or insufficient current
Excessively fast travel speed
Ideal parameter match
Overly dry air supply

rationales.CHOICE-1: Slow/cold cuts leave adherent bottom dross.

rationales.CHOICE-2: Slow travel lets molten metal solidify on the lower edge, forming heavy dross.

rationales.stem: Due to kerf angle in PAC, a good practice is to place the 'good side' of the cut:

choices.text: On the scrap side
On the workpiece side that must meet size/tolerance
Randomly; kerf angle is symmetrical
Always on the operator’s left
On the side where squareness is most critical
Opposite the direction of travel always
It does not matter

rationales.CHOICE-2: PAC kerf is not perfectly square; orient the torch so the true edge is on the kept side.
Plan cut direction so the squarer edge is on the finished side.

rationales.stem: Due to kerf angle in PAC, a good practice is to place the 'good side' of the cut:

choices.text: On the scrap side
On the side where squareness is most critical
Opposite the direction of travel always
It does not matter

rationales.CHOICE-2: Plan cut direction so the squarer edge is on the finished side.

rationales.stem: Prominent lag lines trailing far behind the torch usually indicate:

choices.text: Correct travel speed
Excessive travel speed
Standoff too small
Perfect angularity
Correct speed and current
Travel speed too fast
Travel speed too slow
Proper height only

rationales.CHOICE-2: If the jet lags too far, travel is too fast for full penetration.
Excess speed increases lag/drag lines; adjust speed or current.

rationales.stem: Prominent lag lines trailing far behind the torch usually indicate:

choices.text: Correct speed and current
Travel speed too fast
Travel speed too slow
Proper height only

rationales.CHOICE-2: Excess speed increases lag/drag lines; adjust speed or current.

rationales.stem: A good practice for piercing with PAC is to:

choices.text: Start right on the plate surface to reduce blowback
Pierce at elevated height/angle to avoid blowback into the nozzle
Always pierce from the edge only
Lower amperage to minimum and drag the tip
Pierce at cut height to save time
Pierce at a higher pierce height, then lower to cut height
Pierce with the nozzle touching
Never pierce—edge start only

rationales.CHOICE-2: Piercing higher/angled directs molten ejecta away from the orifices.
Higher pierce height protects consumables from molten blowback.

rationales.stem: A good practice for piercing with PAC is to:

choices.text: Pierce at cut height to save time
Pierce at a higher pierce height, then lower to cut height
Pierce with the nozzle touching
Never pierce—edge start only

rationales.CHOICE-2: Higher pierce height protects consumables from molten blowback.

rationales.stem: What is the advantage of pilot-arc or HF start in PAC?

choices.text: No need for a power source
Reliable arc initiation without contacting the work
Eliminates the need for air supply
Allows cutting of any non‑conductive materials
Requires scraping the nozzle on the work
Initiates the arc without dragging the nozzle
Reduces need for PPE
Increases consumable wear

rationales.CHOICE-2: Pilot/HF start lights the arc without tip contact, reducing wear.
Non-contact starts protect the nozzle and improve reliability.

rationales.stem: What is the advantage of pilot-arc or HF start in PAC?

choices.text: Requires scraping the nozzle on the work
Initiates the arc without dragging the nozzle
Reduces need for PPE
Increases consumable wear

rationales.CHOICE-2: Non-contact starts protect the nozzle and improve reliability.

rationales.stem: What is the advantage of pilot-arc or HF start in PAC?

choices.text: Requires scraping the nozzle on the work
Initiates the arc without dragging the nozzle
Reduces need for PPE
Increases consumable wear

rationales.CHOICE-2: Non-contact starts protect the nozzle and improve reliability.

rationales.stem: Which polarity is typical for air plasma cutting systems?

choices.text: AC only
DCEN (electrode negative)
DCEP (electrode positive)
Either polarity with no effect

rationales.CHOICE-2: Air plasma torches commonly use DCEN (electrode negative).

rationales.stem: Which polarity is typical for air plasma cutting systems?

choices.text: AC only
DCEN (electrode negative)
DCEP (electrode positive)
Either polarity with no effect

rationales.CHOICE-2: Air plasma torches commonly use DCEN (electrode negative).

rationales.stem: Which polarity is typical for air plasma cutting systems?

choices.text: AC only
DCEN (electrode negative)
DCEP (electrode positive)
Either polarity with no effect

rationales.CHOICE-2: Air plasma torches commonly use DCEN (electrode negative).

rationales.stem: Which polarity is typical for air plasma cutting systems?

choices.text: AC only
DCEN (electrode negative)
DCEP (electrode positive)
Either polarity with no effect

rationales.CHOICE-2: Air plasma torches commonly use DCEN: electrode negative, work positive.

rationales.stem: How should torch standoff be managed in plasma arc cutting (PAC)?

choices.text: Always drag the tip regardless of torch design
Maintain the proper standoff/drag per the torch to protect consumables
Closer is always better
Farther is always better

rationales.CHOICE-2: Correct standoff prevents nozzle damage and preserves cut quality.

rationales.stem: The compressor delivers 5.0 scfm at 90 psi. A 45 A hand plasma cutter requires at least 6.0 scfm at 90 psi. What should you do?

choices.text: Run as is — the cut will just be slower
Turn current down to 20 A and the issue disappears
Provide ≥6.0 scfm (bigger compressor/air line) or run a smaller current and nozzle matched to available flow
Raise pressure to 120 psi with the same compressor

rationales.CHOICE-3: Too little flow causes an unstable arc and premature consumable wear; meet the flow spec or down‑rate to match available air.

rationales.stem: The gauge shows 6 bar at idle but drops to 4 bar while cutting. The edge is rough and the arc wanders. What should you check first?

choices.text: Switch polarity to DCEN
Compressor capacity/hose size and any restrictions in the air path
Add a 50 m extension cord — it will help
Reduce the standoff to zero
choices.stem: How should torch standoff be managed in plasma arc cutting (PAC)?

choices.text: Always drag the tip regardless of design
Maintain the proper standoff/drag per torch design to protect consumables
Closer is always better
Farther is always better

rationales.CHOICE-2: A pressure drop under load points to inadequate flow or a restrictive/undersized air supply path.

choices.stem: Where is it best to place a moisture/oil separator (dryer) for PAC?

choices.text: Downstream of the compressor, close to the plasma cutter, with regular draining
Upstream of the compressor — that keeps the whole system dry
Not needed; shop air is already ‘dry’
After the torch — on the hose

rationales.CHOICE-1: Place the dryer after the compressor/receiver and as close to the machine as practical for best removal of moisture and oil.

choices.stem: When piercing 12 mm plate, how do you reduce blowback spatter onto the nozzle?

choices.text: Touch the nozzle to the plate and immediately start moving
Raise to 1.5–2× normal standoff and slightly tilt away until the jet breaks through, then level out
Lower the air pressure to the minimum
Pierce on the very edge of the part
choices.CHOICE-2: Correct standoff prevents nozzle damage and preserves cut quality.

choices.stem: How should torch standoff be managed in plasma arc cutting (PAC)?

choices.text: Always drag the tip regardless of design
Maintain the proper standoff/drag per torch design to protect consumables
Closer is always better
Farther is always better

rationales.CHOICE-2: Extra height and a slight tilt during the pierce reduce molten blowback onto the nozzle and extend consumable life.

choices.stem: Where should lead‑in/lead‑out be placed when nesting parts for cutting?

choices.text: On the ‘good’ finished edge — it’s more accurate
On scrap, outside the finished contour
Always centered on each side
No lead‑in at all — start right on the contour
choices.CHOICE-2: Correct standoff prevents nozzle damage and preserves cut quality.

choices.stem: How should torch standoff be managed in plasma arc cutting (PAC)?

choices.text: Always drag the tip regardless of design
Maintain the proper standoff/drag per torch design to protect consumables
Closer is always better
Farther is always better

rationales.CHOICE-2: Place lead‑in/out on the scrap side so start/stop defects never land on the finished edge.

choices.stem: Inspection shows a deep pit in the electrode face (hafnium). What should you do?

choices.text: Flip the electrode and use the other end
Keep running until it burns through — there’s life left
Replace the electrode (and nozzle if needed) to prevent double‑arcing and kerf angle
Increase current for self‑cleaning

rationales.CHOICE-3: A deep crater indicates wear; continuing risks double‑arcing and degraded cut quality.

choices.stem: After the torch was dropped the swirl ring cracked. How will this defect show up in cutting?

choices.text: The arc becomes brighter and more stable
No effect — that part is cosmetic
Unstable arc, bevelled kerf, accelerated nozzle wear
Severe heating of the work clamp cable

rationales.CHOICE-3: A damaged swirl ring disrupts plasma stabilization — arc shape and edge quality suffer.

choices.stem: You’re getting a pronounced bottom burr in corners and at hole exit. What technique change helps?

choices.text: Speed up through the corner by 30–40%
Slow down 20–30% before corners and at hole exit
Raise current by 10 A only in corners
Increase standoff to 5–6 mm
choices.CHOICE-2: Correct standoff prevents nozzle damage and preserves cut quality.

choices.stem: What is the advantage of pilot‑arc or HF start in PAC?

choices.text: They require scraping the nozzle on the work
They initiate the arc without dragging the nozzle
They reduce the need for shielding
They increase consumable wear

rationales.CHOICE-2: In corners/exits the jet loses energy; a brief slow‑down keeps the jet trailing under control and reduces dross.

choices.stem: Your machine’s duty cycle is 60% at 40 A. You cut 6 minutes out of 10 and thermal protection tripped. Which statement is correct?

choices.text: This is normal — add pauses or reduce current
Change polarity and the protection will disable
Lubricate the fan — that will help
Raise air pressure to 10 bar

rationales.CHOICE-1: A 60% duty cycle allows at most 6 minutes on per 10‑minute cycle at rated conditions; add cool‑down time or lower current.

choices.stem: Powered through a 50 m extension cord (1.5 mm²), the unit sags and the arc breaks. Your fix?

choices.text: Use a shorter, larger‑gauge cord or connect closer to the panel
Lower the air pressure to 3 bar
Increase travel speed
Add another air dryer

rationales.CHOICE-1: Long/thin power leads cause voltage drop — use a shorter and thicker supply cable.

choices.stem: Where should the work clamp be attached for PAC?

choices.text: On painted surface far away — the sparks will reach
On clean metal as close to the cut as possible
On the table, through rubber pads
On a neighboring part — no difference

rationales.CHOICE-2: A clean, short return path improves arc stability and cut quality.

choices.stem: The arc occasionally ‘doubles’ and the kerf is trapezoidal. What does this suggest?

choices.text: Normal operation — a sign of good speed
Worn nozzle/electrode (ovalized orifice, deep electrode crater)
Wrong polarity
Work clamp cable is too short

rationales.CHOICE-2: Worn consumables cause double‑arcing and kerf angle (bevel).

choices.stem: How can you recognize optimal PAC speed on mild steel?

choices.text: Heavy bottom dross and horizontal lag lines
Nearly vertical lag lines and a thin, easily removed dross
A heavy top bevel — means it’s ‘cold’
Absolutely no line marks on the edge

rationales.CHOICE-2: At proper speed the lag lines are close to vertical and dross is thin and easy to remove.

choices.stem: You must cut Ø14 mm holes in 10 mm plate. How can you improve hole geometry with a hand PAC?

choices.text: Cut at normal speed — holes are no different
Reduce speed by 30–40% and use a short lead‑in with exit onto scrap
Increase standoff to 6–8 mm
Always cut top‑down clockwise

rationales.CHOICE-2: Small holes need a slower speed and careful lead‑in/out to limit taper and burrs.

choices.stem: Cutting expanded/perforated metal causes constant arc outages. What helps?

choices.text: Use a constant pilot‑arc mode (if available)
Increase standoff to 10 mm
Lower air pressure to the minimum
Install a larger nozzle without changing current

rationales.CHOICE-1: A constant pilot arc maintains reignition while traversing gaps and cutouts.

choices.stem: Cutting galvanized steel produces heavy fumes. What should you do?

choices.text: Continue — the fumes are harmless
Provide effective extraction/water table and respiratory PPE
Add oil to the air — it will reduce dust
Lower air pressure to 2 bar — it will be cleaner

rationales.CHOICE-2: Zinc fumes are hazardous — use local exhaust/water table and appropriate respiratory protection or remove the coating first.

choices.stem: The cutter’s stated air demand is 4.5 scfm. About how many liters per minute is that?

choices.text: ≈45 L/min
≈85 L/min
≈128 L/min
≈4.5 L/min

choices.stem: Hand cutting along a straightedge, the edge ‘wanders’ due to inconsistent standoff. What can you use to stabilize height?

choices.text: A drag shield/stand‑off shoe or wheel, or a distance ring on the torch
Press the nozzle firmly onto the plate
Increase current by 20 A
Cut faster — the arc will straighten out

rationales.CHOICE-1: A mechanical stand‑off helps hold a constant height during manual cutting, improving cut quality.
rationales.CHOICE-2: Non‑contact starts protect the nozzle and improve reliability.
